item.title: New Details About Canceled Batman Game Appear Online
item.description:
Some new concept art for the long-canceled Batman game - dubbed Project Sabbath - has surfaced online. While there have been numerous concept art leaks surrounding this shelved Batman game in the past, the latest batch shows off the best glimpse so far at some key characters, including an older Bruce Wayne.

Although never officially announced, Project Sabbath has been a hot topic of discussion among Batman fans since details about it began percolating about six years ago. Project Sabbath was reportedly in development at WB Games Montreal and intended to be a follow-up to 2015's Batman: Arkham Knight . The scrapped Batman game would have starred Damian Wayne as Gothamâ€™s new Dark Knight, set in a future timeline years after Bruce Wayne's retirement. However, Project Sabbath was ultimately shelved in favor of Gotham Knights , which launched in 2022 to lukewarm reception.

All these years later, a new batch of concept art and in-game character models for the canceled Damian Wayne Batman game has made its way online. Sourced from former WB Montreal character artist Rodrigue Pralier and shared by MP1ST, the images depict a visibly older Bruce Wayne who's equipped with a cane - reminiscent of Batman Beyond 's Terry McGinnis-era Bruce. His son, Damian Wayne, can also be seen suited up in what seems to be a slimmer and more agile Batsuit, along with blue eyes, a short haircut, and some scarring on his face.

Fresh Concept Art Provides New Look at Canceled Batman Game's Bruce Wayne, Damian Wayne, Killer Croc, and More

There are some character model options for Killer Croc as well, where most of them look more human than his monstrous Batman: Arkham counterpart, but one bears a striking resemblance to a Predator and another looks somewhat inspired by Baraka from the Mortal Kombat series. Lastly, the Huntress is featured in concept art that shows off her black-and-purple cowl, as well as some character models displaying her classic black-white-purple suit.

Project Sabbath was purportedly intended to be the fifth entry in the Batman Arkhamverse, but some of these designs suggest it may have broken from that continuity. Still, it's unfortunate to see another seemingly-promising DC game cut down before its time, especially following the cancelation of Monolith's Wonder Woman game earlier this year. Thankfully, WB has at least reiterated its commitment to core franchises like Batman and Harry Potter since then, and rumors from credible sources even point to Rocksteady possibly working on a new Batman Beyond game in the wake of Suicide Squad: Kill the Justice League 's enormous failure.

item.title: Obtained Vessels Achievement Guide in Elden Ring Nightreign
item.description:
There are many achievements to get in Elden Ring Nightreign that are obtained through actions in the Roundtable Hold. While many of them require you to simply complete expeditions or run into randomized raids, others, such as Obtained Vessels, focus on items you get that carry over between expeditions.

Obtained Vessels tells you to simply get a, "great many," though an exact number is not given. While some vessels can be purchased from Small Jar Bazaar, this won't be enough to get the achievement. Here's exactly how many you need to get, and also what a vessel is.

What are Vessels in Elden Ring Nightreign

Vessels are the overall name for Urns, Grails, Chalices, and Goblets , which are the things you place relics into for each character. You can see your relics and vessels any time in the Roundtable Hold by interacting with the Relic Rite pedestal. From here, you'll be able to see how many vessels you have, sectioned off by each character. You initially start with one urn for each character, and these won't count towards the total number you'll need for the achievement.

How Many Vessels Do You Need For Obtained Vessels In Elden Ring Nighreign

In total, you'll need an additional twelve vessels to get the achievement . There are two main ways of getting Vessels:

  • Purchasing them from Small Jar Bazaar.
  • Completing Remembrance Quests.

Your main source for Vessels will be purchasing them from Small Jar Bazaar, as there aren't enough Remembrance Quest rewards to get this achievement. This will require a good bit of Murk, but unlocking new Vessels will require you to beat Nightlords, which should give you more than enough.

The initial stock of Small Jar Bazaar will grow whenever you defeat four Nightlords and make the Night Aspect expedition appear. You'll then unlock additional new ones once you beat the final boss of the game, the Night Aspect. In total, you'll be able to buy eleven Vessels from Small Jar Bazaar , meaning you'll only need to complete part of one character's Remembrance Quest in order to get a vessel and get the achievement.

Purchasing all Vessels from Small Jar Bazaar will cost 18,600 Murk in total .

Getting Vessels from Remembrance Quests is different for each one, and some Remembrance Quests are much more difficult to complete than others. If you aren't focusing on Remembrance Quests and just want this achievement, the Recluse's Remembrance is fairly quick for giving a vessel , and only requires you to fight one smaller boss during an expedition to get the Vessel.

8 Images
8 Images

item.title: Crimson Desert Devs Respond to Release Date Rumors
item.description:
Recent claims about the much-awaited release of Crimson Desert have been cleared up, as developer Pearl Abyss responded to rumors suggesting an early November launch. The action-adventure game Crimson Desert follows main character Kliff and his Greymanes friends as they travel across the land of Pywel.

Crimson Desert first drew major attention when its first gameplay trailer was shown at The Game Awards 2020, impressing viewers with its open-world exploration, smooth fighting, and amazing graphics. At that time, Pearl Abyss shared its plans for the game and announced a goal to release it in winter 2021. However, the studio later delayed the game without giving a new date, saying it needed more time to make the game bigger and better. Crimson Desert finally returned with a new trailer at Gamescom Opening Night Live 2023, showing off its fast combat, better graphics, and new features like shops and interactive animal companions.

A few months ago, a new trailer shown during The Game Awards confirmed that Crimson Desert is now aiming for a late 2025 release. But a recent report from Korean outlet MTN claimed to have found a more exact date, saying that Pearl Abyss was planning for a possible November 2, 2025, release. In response, Pearl Abyss denied this, telling Insider Gaming that no interview with MTN had happened and that no official release date had been given to the outlet. The developer stressed that any official announcement about the release will come directly from the company when it is ready.

Crimson Desert Release Date Rumors Shut Down by Developers

Hopefully, Crimson Desert will avoid more delays and release within its planned window. Pearl Abyss has confirmed that the game is planned for a worldwide launch at the same time on PC and consoles. Interestingly, Sony had reportedly tried to make Crimson Desert a platform exclusive. However, Pearl Abyss decided to publish the game independently. According to what it told investors, the developer believes this choice gives better long-term advantages, since Pearl Abyss already has a worldwide publishing system with regional offices ready to handle an international release.

In addition to the confirmed platforms, recent rumors suggest that Crimson Desert might also come to the upcoming Nintendo Switch 2. A product listing on GameStop hinted at the chance of a Switch 2 version, which, if true, would let Pearl Abyss reach even more players. However, there are reasonable worries about whether the Switch 2's hardware can deliver the same graphic quality and performance seen on stronger systems like PlayStation 5 and Xbox Series X/S, which might lead to compromises to the gameâ€™s ambitious presentation.

item.title: Disney Dreamlight Valley's Best Money-Making Route is Virtually Unbeatable
item.description:
Star Coins are essential in Disney Dreamlight Valley , as they unlock everything from new biomes and inventory expansions to premium furniture, fencing, and clothing. The game offers several lucrative ways to earn Star Coins, like catching the rare Here and There Fish, mining for valuable gems, cooking high-value meals, or selling foraged items. But only one method delivers fast, consistent, and scalable profits. With the right crop rotation, players can earn their first million Star Coins in under 15 hours of gameplay.

Disney Dreamlight Valley â€™s best money-making path follows a three-stage farming strategy. It begins with carrots, which are cheap and offer a fast way to build early-game funds. Then, it transitions to okra for a higher profit margin, before reaching the final stage of pumpkins, which deliver the highest profits per crop and scale exceptionally well.

The Carrot, Okra, Pumpkin Strategy Explained

Early Dreamlight Valley players should start with farming carrots. They only cost 10 coins and require a single watering. Plus, the wait time is just 15 minutes, meaning players can cycle through multiple carrot harvests in an hour and stack thousands of coins. As players gather coins, they may be tempted to rush to the Forgotten Lands because of pumpkins, but thatâ€™s a mistake. The Glade is cheaper to unlock, and it gives access to okra seeds. These cost 135 coins and yield three crops selling for 114 each. Thatâ€™s 342 coins per seed, more than double the investment. Okra grows in two hours and only needs one watering.

Once players unlock the Forgotten Lands, they should shift to pumpkin farming. Pumpkin seeds cost 275 coins, but each pumpkin sells for 664, providing a profit of 389 coins per unit. With a 99-tile field, players can earn over 38,000 Star Coins per harvest. Pairing this with a farming companion boosts the return even further. With max energy and food buffs stacked, the companion will trigger duplicate pumpkins and easily double the yield. The up-front seed cost is high, yes, but the ROI crushes every other method.

Why Other Methods of DDV Money-Making Waste Time

Mining seems promising, especially with high-value gems like Topaz or Diamond, but the gains are capped by long cooldowns and RNG-driven rewards. Players canâ€™t control the drop rate or location availability. Fishing has the same problem. Rare fish like Fugu or Lobster sell well, but theyâ€™re weather or time-dependent and limited to specific spots. Crafting and cooking may seem promising, but the profit margins are low unless tied to quests. Farming is the only method that offers guaranteed returns, short turnaround times, and scalable rewards for both active and idle players.

Smart Upgrades That Boost Star Coin Collection

Once pumpkins become the main income source, players should focus on staggering plant times across plots to minimize downtime. To push profits even further, pumpkins can be cooked into Grilled Vegetables at Remyâ€™s kitchen. Each dish sells for 606 coins, which is nearly 2x the raw pumpkinâ€™s value. Itâ€™s also a smart move to eat high-stamina meals like Berry Salad or Grilled Veggie Platter before a harvest session. A maxed-out energy bar helps avoid breaks and also activates the Well Fed Bonus. This allows players to take advantage of chain-sprint and collect faster during large-scale harvesting runs with no extra energy expenditure.

Several structural upgrades also multiply efficiency. Goofyâ€™s stall expansions in each biome unlock more seeds and boost sell prices through progressive upgrades. Biome wells, when unlocked and fully upgraded, act as teleport hubs. This saves time running back and forth between Glade of Trust and Forgotten Lands. House storage upgrades are also essential. A full pumpkin harvest can lead to inventory overflow and returning to Scroogeâ€™s shop mid-harvest breaks momentum. With higher storage, players can batch-sell when prices are favorable or during shop resets. The Miracle Growth Elixir also helps speed up crop cycles when working under time constraints or trying to squeeze in multiple harvests within a short window. Together, these tricks help compound the playerâ€™s earnings in the most efficient manner.

item.title: Nintendo Switch Online Classics - N64 Game Tier List
item.description:
Quick Links

  • S Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics
  • A Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics
  • B Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics
  • C Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics

Nintendo Switch Online â€™s library of classic Nintendo 64 games available as part of its Expansion Pack is very diverse, containing some of the systemâ€™s most beloved titles. From thoughtful single-player experiences to frantic multiplayer party games, Nintendo Switch Online subscribers with the Expansion Pack have many options available for any occasion.

Like with any console, though, some games stand out above the rest. Most of the Nintendo 64 games selected for Nintendo Switch Online are fan favorites for the console, but others are viewed by some as the best games of all time, which can now be enhanced further with exclusive Switch 2 features. Below are some of the consoleâ€™s masterpieces and hidden gems, as well as a few that havenâ€™t aged as gracefully.

S Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics

The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time

Rated as one of the best games of all time, The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time easily finds a spot in the S-tier of the N64 Switch Online Classics catalog. Its world and storytelling have stayed with players for decades, and its influential game design is still used in modern Zelda titles.

The Legend of Zelda: Majoraâ€™s Mask

The Legend of Zelda: Majoraâ€™s Mask follows Ocarina of Time â€™s story with an experience that is just high quality. Instead of the lighthearted adventure of its predecessor, Majoraâ€™s Mask takes on a darker tone, giving more attention to how its side characters in a doomed Termina.

Super Mario 64

As a pioneer of the 3D platforming genre, Super Mario 64 still holds up as one of the best. Mario is extremely fun to control, turning every level into a playground. This game is constantly referenced by newer installments, making it a must-play for fans of the series.

Mario Party 2

The spot for best Nintendo 64 Mario Party game is hotly contested, as each offers something more than the others. Mario Party 2 only just triumphs because of its themed boards and selection of minigames.

Banjo-Kazooie

While Super Mario 64 revolutionized the 3D platformer, Banjo-Kazooie was the first Nintendo 64 title to perfect the formula. Each world feels expansive but never outstays its welcome. The many collectibles available give players a reason to explore every nook and cranny.

Banjo-Tooie

Banjo-Tooie is a similar experience to the original, but handled very differently. Rather than Banjo-Kazooie straightforward, self-contained levels, the sequel focuses on interconnected worlds and backtracking, more in line with a Metroidvania. The original is a charming, smaller experience, but Banjo-Tooie makes the world feel more expansive.

A Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics

Paper Mario

Paper Mario laid the foundation for the future of the series, and is a contender for one of the best RPGs on the Nintendo 64. The stylized graphics are still fantastic multiple console generations later, and it laid the foundation for the series moving forward.

Pokemon Snap

Pokemon Snap is essentially a slow-paced rail shooter that tasks players with capturing the perfect images of the gameâ€™s Pokemon. Itâ€™s a relatively short game, but figuring out different interactions and navigating onto different paths makes the experience memorable. Players who enjoy the game can then move onto the Switch sequel, New Pokemon Snap .

Perfect Dark

Perfect Dark is everything that players love about GoldenEye 007 and more. Not weighed down by an existing IP, Perfect Dark is given full creative freedom to offer one of the best first-person shooter experiences on the Nintendo 64.

Wave Race 64

Instead of a standard track, Wave Race 64 has players racing on open water, with physics that still feels great today. Itâ€™s one of the consoleâ€™s best racing experiences, with online features that Nintendo Switch Online subscribers should take advantage of.

Sin and Punishment

One of the platformâ€™s underrated gems, Sin and Punishment is one of the best shooters on the platform. It offers an interesting story and great visuals, and while it is often overlooked, it is well worth playersâ€™ time.

Mario Party 3

Mario Party 3 is the favorite of many fans, and with good reason. It takes most of the ideas of the previous games and makes it more expansive. However, when comparing mini-games and strategy, it takes a step back from Mario Party 2 , but only narrowly. It remains one of the best games the franchise has to offer.

F-Zero X

The exhilarating racing gameplay of F-Zero X is some of the best in the series, rivaled only by its GameCube sequel F-Zero GX . The high-speed gameplay is very challenging, which some players might not enjoy, but is a thrilling experience for those that do.

Star Fox 64

Arguably the best game in the series, Star Fox 64 â€™s branching pathways make the rail shooter feel like an arcade experience to play at home. Now with the added online multiplayer capabilities, the Nintendo Switch Online version may the definitive way to play.

Mario Tennis

Looking back, Mario Tennis can seem simpler than its modern iterations, but this is what makes it great. Itâ€™s a great game to pick up and play with friends at any skill level online, with enough depth to allow for competitive gameplay.

B Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics

Mario Kart 64

Mario Kart 64 feels like a standard Mario Kart game, but everything is done to perfection. Nintendo Switch and Switch 2 owners may get more out of Mario Kart World and Mario Kart 8 Deluxe , but Mario Kart 64 perfects the core elements of the series.

Pokemon Puzzle League

Straying away from turn-based RPG combat, Pokemon Puzzle League â€™s puzzles offer players a lot of variety. It features multiple different game modes, but with Nintendo Switch Online, intense online multiplayer sessions give the game more life.

Mario Party

While it may be the origin of the series, Mario Party sits just below its sequels. This entry is still worth playing, but the additional features and lack of injuries sustained in the later entries make them much more approachable.

Kirby 64: The Crystal Shards

Kirby 64: The Crystal Shards is one of the most unique games in the series, allowing players to combine abilities. The gameplay does feel slow at times, but for Kirby fans, this game canâ€™t be skipped.

Mario Golf

Mario Golf holds up really well, feeling very close to the experience of the modern Mario sports titles. While Mario Tennis takes a simulator-like approach, Mario Golf leans into the more cartoonish aspects of the series.

Yoshiâ€™s Story

Despite having high expectations to live up to from its predecessor, Yoshiâ€™s Island , Yoshiâ€™s Story manages to hold its own. Itâ€™s not very challenging, but it makes for a very cozy experience with a great aesthetic.

Extreme-G

Another hidden gem, Extreme-G combines combat and racing really well. Its high-speed gameplay is comparable to F-Zero , but its weapons give players the chance to tip the scales in their favor.

Pilotwings 64

As one of the Nintendo 64â€™s launch games, Pilotwings 64 is still a great experience and a definite step up from the SNES version. Itâ€™s full of personality and Easter eggs, making a great addition to the Nintendo Switch Online collection.

Excitebike 64

Excitebike 64 plays how players would expect a 3D version of the NES original to feel. Players looking for an alternative racing experience should try this out, but it can be difficult to get used to at first.

1080 Snowboarding

Another unconventional racing game, 1080 Snowboarding is a very smooth gameplay experience. Though it is light on content, if offers a lot of replayability with its Time Trials and its score-based modes make players reconsider their approach to each course.

GoldenEye 007

First-person shooters wouldnâ€™t be what they are today without GoldenEye 007 . Unfortunately, it has started to show its age. The level design is the high quality players can expect from Rare, and the multiplayer mode is great with online functionality, but the gameâ€™s controls are not the best without changing some settings.

Custom Robo 2

The toy-like nature of Custom Robo 2 â€™s customization features are unparalleled, making for intense battles without losing its sense of fun and creativity. This game is currently only available with a Japanese Nintendo Switch account, though.

Blast Corps

Blast Corps is one of Rareâ€™s more overlooked titles on the Nintendo 64, but is no less enjoyable. There are plenty of destruction-based puzzles for players to solve, with enough variety to keep the game feeling fresh.

Killer Instinct Gold

As one of the few fighting game experiences on the Nintendo Switch Online, Killer Instinct Gold is a great experience. It is an enhanced version of Killer Instinct 2 , and is arguably one of the best fighting games on the Nintendo 64.

C Tier N64 Games on Nintendo Switch Online Classics

Custom Robo

Though Custom Robo has fewer gameplay features than its sequel, it has a much better plot. However, being restricted to Japanese accounts, there is no official translation, restricting who would benefit from the story.

Ridge Racer 64

While it is a solid racing game experience, Ridge Racer 64 is overshadowed by the many other racing games on the system, and other games in the franchise. Like the rest of the Ridge Racer series, its soundtrack is a highlight, but isnâ€™t as bold as other games in the genre.

Iggyâ€™s Reckinâ€™ Balls

Iggyâ€™s Reckinâ€™ Balls is by no means a bad game, offering a unique racing game experience that canâ€™t easily be compared to the rest of the Nintendo 64â€™s library. However, its short bursts of fun donâ€™t give it much staying power for longer play sessions.

Pokemon Stadium

Hindered by the missing Transfer Pak functionality, Pokemon Stadium on Nintendo Switch Online doesnâ€™t feel the same as its release on the Nintendo 64. It includes some great Mario Party -esque mini-games, but being restricted to Rental Pokemon makes the game more difficult to enjoy.

Harvest Moon 64

Harvest Moon 64 was a great game for its time, but modernizations made to the formula make this entry feel more dated. Its visuals still look great, but the experience feels quite slow and limited.

Shadow Man

Shadow Man is a hidden gem in Nintendo Switch Onlineâ€™s Nintendo 64 collection, but it feels a little rough to play in the modern era. For a slightly better experience, the Shadow Man remaster has some modern improvements and includes content missing from the original.

Turok: Dinosaur Hunter

With a similar problem to Shadow Man , Turok: Dinosaur Hunter received a remaster on Nintendo Switch which is a major improvement. The Nintendo Switch Online version can give players a hint of what the game is like, but feels like a downgrade in comparison to the rereleases.

Turok 2: Seeds of Evil

Like the original, Turok 2: Seeds of Evil has a more enjoyable remaster. Regardless, which of the two is better comes down to personal preference. Turok: Dinosaur Hunter is a much more streamlined experience, but the sequelâ€™s expansive levels give the player more freedom to explore.

Jet Force Gemini

Another Rare game that suffers the same fate as GoldenEye 007 , Jet Force Gemini is another game brought down by its controls, even at the time of its release. Itâ€™s a great collectathon in concept, but high difficulty and awkward controls can make this a difficult game to recommend.

Pokemon Stadium 2

On its original console, Pokemon Stadium 2 was a clear step up because of the addition of Generation 2 Pokemon. On Nintendo Switch Online, with the exception of the minigames, Pokemon Stadium 2 is a step-down from the original because of its worse Rental system.

WinBack

Considered one of the first third-person shooters with cover mechanics, WinBack is an enjoyable and innovative experience. However, it offers very little challenge, with a fairly flat difficulty curve throughout.

Dr. Mario 64

The Nintendo 64 installment of the Dr. Mario series sadly has little to offer the original. At best, itâ€™s more Dr. Mario for fans that enjoy the game, but at worst, it feels like one of the more sluggish versions to play.
